ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Russian L3 continues developing the skills of L2, focusing on the vocabulary of love life, illness, time, and quite a bit on verbs of motion. This year, I felt more comfortably able to speak about whatever I wished, given the broader scope of the course.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
The strengths of this course lie in its consistency. The schedule is clearly set out from day 1, with daily homework as well as biweekly quizzes and tests that alternate each week. This does result in a bit of monotony after about two or three months, but mostly allows for productive time management.

The weaknesses of this course lie in so diligently following the textbook. Luckily, my professor this year kept our small class engaged by supplementing materials from outside the textbook, and picking and choosing bits of the textbook they found valuable (some of the other professors in the department did not follow suit). I think this approach should be standard practice, because it truly facilitated a more productive and fun classroom environment.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to another student if they intend to complete the language requirement or are fascinated by Russian literature and have a strong background in Cyrillic.
